name: nytimes
text:
China is about to try to launch an orbiter, lander and rover to Mars. The mission, Tianwen-1, is expected to lift off as early as Thursday. 

With just one launch, the country is hoping to catch up with decades of American success on the red planet. https://t.co/X43Z315eOl

name: nytimes
text:
Here's a look at the Tianwen-1 spacecraft, which weighs more than 5 tons. 

Its name means “Questions to Heaven,” which comes from a classical Chinese poem (also sometimes translated as “Heavenly Questions.”). https://t.co/X43Z315eOl https://t.co/huA6f4hA8B

name: nytimes
text: The orbiter will circle Mars for 687 days — a Martian year — and conduct its own scientific observations. It will also communicate with a lander and rover – these will try to descend to Mars’s surface 2 or 3 months after arriving in orbit in February. https://t.co/X43Z315eOl

name: nytimes
text:
More than just China’s pride is at stake in the launch of Tianwen-1. 

“The Communist Party of China wants to prove to the world that they are actually a legitimate alternative to a U.S.-led space order,” one analyst said. https://t.co/X43Z315eOl
